body: @r00ster91 Any chance you can try this on the latest master?
Sorry, I forgot testing this on master. I just tried it in 3.3 and I can still reproduce this.

This also happens with a french keyboard layout with GLFW 3.2.1 and master. Calling `glfwGetKeyName(GLFW_KEY_1, 10)` yields `1` instead of `&`. 

I remember that this was working fine when #981 got closed. So I reverted to 8597002a177beb56db09cd1a9fca0025687dc706 and tested again: same issue. Looks like this is caused by an environment change (Ubuntu 16.04 -> 18.04) rather than a breaking change in GLFW.

The problem is here:

https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/d834f01ca43c0f5ddd31b00a7fc2f48abbafa3da/src/x11_window.c#L2802 

The `group` argument is not necessarily 0.  The actual fix is to add a `group` field in _glfw.x11.xkb:

```C
XkbStateRec state;
if (XkbGetState(_glfw.x11.display, XkbUseCoreKbd, &state) == Success)
    _glfw.x11.xkb.group =  state.group;
```

Then use that value in the call to `XkbKeycodeToKeysym`. 

I have multiple keyboard layouts configured (en-UK primary, fr-Fr secondary) and depending on which one is selected, the group index changes. (I do not know if this is a new behavior compared to Ubuntu 16.04). As a result, anyone testing this will not necessarily see it break, depending on which keyboard layout is first.

The group value should be tracked and updated when the keyboard layout changes. See [Determining Keyboard State](https://www.x.org/releases/X11R7.6/doc/libX11/specs/XKB/xkblib.html#determining_keyboard_state) and the following topic. This would also be a step forward to implementing #1201.

Here's a working fix: https://github.com/db47h/glfw/commit/5796f163c7ae5af03cdc81c402f5fc6f37abd757

At least it works for me on Ubuntu 18.04.  

EDIT: this code doesn't check for device ids... Won't behave well for people with more than one physical keyboard plugged in. Or is the keyboard layout setting global? Ideas, anyone?
@db47h I already saw someone with an azerty and a qwerty keyboard plugged in. The two keyboard had both different layout. It was on X11

And to make things worse, there's no way to choose which device to query with `glfwGetKeyName()`. I'm not sure how to handle this correctly.

EDIT: converting a beast like Xkb to a handful of API calls is of course not possible. We just need to provide a sane default behavior.

After putting some more thought into it, and keeping in mind that the 3.x API cannot be changed, an ok-ish solution to this is that `glfwGetKeyName` should return the key name for the default keyboard (`XkbUseCoreKbd`). The state change event handler also only tracks changes for this device.

So https://github.com/db47h/glfw/commit/5796f163c7ae5af03cdc81c402f5fc6f37abd757 should work for most users. For those with multiple keyboards, key callbacks will trigger for any keyboard, but it will still be impossible to query the actual key name for secondary keyboards. 

@elmindreda do you want me to submit a PR with this?

In order to address these kind of issues in GLFW 4.0, I believe that the proper course of action is to implement raw keyboard events like SDL does: have a a well defined scancode enumeration common to all platforms (the platform specific GLFW event handler will map platform specific scancodes to these), and push that GFLW scancode (layout independent) + key name (layout dependent) to the application in key events. That way, applications that are only interested in actual key positions, like games, can use only scancodes, while others can use the key names (for shortcuts for example where you want to use layout dependent key names). Mapping scancodes to key names outside of event handlers will still be problematic in a multiple keyboard scenario, but I don't see it as a really serious problem.
@db47h Good work, please do submit a PR!

issue.body:
Fixes #1462 

For users with multiple keyboard layouts configured, `glfwGetKeyName` works fine only with the primary layout (i.e. on Ubuntu 18.04, the first layout in the list). Switching layouts results in changing the group index used in various Xkb API calls. With this commit, the current group index is fetched when initializing keyboard input and an event handler is set up to keep track of any change to this group index.

As a result the scancode -> keyname mapping may change while the program is running (needs to be documented). This also partially addresses #1201: GLFW now receives the event, a complete fix would need to push it to the application.

Note that this code deals only with the default keyboard (see https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/1462#issuecomment-501696245).

body: @elmindreda here you go. Could this be backported in a 3.3 minor release ?
